title: Jesus began his reign in heaven
details: Ample evidence points to the year 1914 as the time when “a crown was given” to the Lord Jesus Christ. He “went out conquering and to complete his conquest.” (Rev. 6:2) He cleansed the heavens in a war against Satan and his demons, who were hurled down to the vicinity of the earth.

title: Satan Challenges Jehovah about Job
details: See IT Volume 2 page 81

title: Egypt attains prominence as first world power
details: See IT Volume 1 pages 686-689

title: Tower of Babel
details: About 200 years after the flood. See: here

title: Jerusalem was destroyed
details: The city walls were breached on Tammuz 9, 607 B.C.E. A month later, on Ab 10, Nebuchadnezzar’s agent, Nebuzaradan, entered the conquered city and began demolition work, burning the temple and other buildings and proceeding to pull down the city walls. Jerusalem’s king and most of her people were exiled to Babylon and her treasures were carried away as plunder.

title: Adam was created
details: It was likely in the fall of the year, for mankind’s most ancient calendars began counting time in the autumn around October 1, or at the first new moon of the lunar civil year.

title: Adam died
details: Finally, after 930 years, most of which was spent in the slow process of dying, Adam returned to the ground from which he was taken, in the year 3096 B.C.E., just as Jehovah had said.

title: Noah was born
details: 126 years after Adam’s death. When his father Lamech named Noah, he said: 'This one will bring us comfort from our work and from the pain of our hands resulting from the ground which Jehovah has cursed.'

title: The flood happened
details: The catastrophic destruction of men and animals by an overwhelming flood in the days of Noah, 2370 B.C.E. This greatest cataclysm in all human history was sent by Jehovah because wicked men had filled the earth with violence. The survival of righteous Noah and his family, eight souls in all, together with selected animals, was by means of a huge ark, or chest.

title: Noah Died
details: Noah lived for 350 years after the Flood.

title: Shem Born
details: See IT Volume 2 919-20

title: Abraham was born
details: Abraham was the tenth generation from Noah through Shem and was born 352 years after the Deluge, in 2018 B.C.E.

title: Sarah was born
details: Abraham was the tenth generation from Noah through Shem and was born 352 years after the Deluge, in 2018 B.C.E.

title: Isaac was born
details: See IT Volume 1 pg 1216-18

title: Abraham was willing to offer up Isaac
details: See https://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/1200000060

title: Jacob was born
details: See IT Volume 1 pg 1242-47

title: Job's Trial
details: See IT Volume 2 page 81

title: Job Died
details: See https://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/1101990079?q=140+years&p=par

title: Moses was born
details: Moses was born in 1593 B.C.E., in Egypt, being the son of Amram, the grandson of Kohath, and the great-grandson of Levi. His mother Jochebed was Kohath’s sister.

title: Moses killed the Egyptian
details: In the 40th year of his life, while making observation of the burdens his Hebrew brothers were bearing, he saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew. In taking up his fellow Israelite’s defense, he killed the Egyptian and buried him in the sand.

title: Moses died
details: He was 120 years old when he died. https://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/1200003118#h=1

title: David was born
details: We know that David was anointed as king over Judah in 1077 B.C.E., when he was 30 years old. So, he must have born around this year.

title: David was anointed as king of Judah
details: David now moved to Hebron, where the older men of Judah anointed him as king over their tribe in 1077 B.C.E., when he was 30 years old.

title: David died
details: David died at at least 70 years old. dhttps://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/1200001130

title: Solomon began construction of the temple
details: In the fourth year of his reign, in the second month of the year (the month Ziv [April-May]), in 1034 B.C.E., Solomon began to build the house of Jehovah on Mount Moriah. (1Ki 6:1) The building of the temple was peacefully quiet; the stones were fitted before being brought to the site, so that no sound of hammers or axes or of any tools of iron was heard. (1Ki 6:7) King Hiram of Tyre cooperated in supplying timbers of cedar and juniper trees in exchange for wheat and oil. (1Ki 5:10-12; 2Ch 2:11-16) He also furnished workmen, including an expert craftsman named Hiram, the son of a Tyrian man and a Hebrew woman. (1Ki 7:13, 14) Solomon conscripted for forced labor 30,000 men, sending them to Lebanon in shifts of 10,000 a month. Each group returned to their homes for two-month periods. Besides these, there were 70,000 burden bearers and 80,000 cutters. These last-named groups were non-Israelites.—1Ki 5:13-18; 2Ch 2:17, 18.

title: Solomon finished construction of the temple
details: The tremendous building project occupied seven and a half years, being concluded in the eighth month, Bul, in 1027 B.C.E. (1Ki 6:37, 38) It appears that it took some time afterward to bring in the utensils and to get everything arranged, for it was in the seventh month, Ethanim, at the time of the Festival of Booths, that the sanctification and inauguration of the temple were carried out by Solomon. (1Ki 8:2; 2Ch 7:8-10) Therefore it must have taken place in the seventh month of 1026 B.C.E., 11 months after completing the building, rather than a month before the structure was completed (in 1027 B.C.E.), as some have thought.

title: Solomon dies
details: Son of King David of the line of Judah; king of Israel from 1037 to 998 B.C.E.

title: Ezekiel is commissioned as a prophet
details: Ezekiel says that he received his commission by the river Chebar in the fifth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin (or in 613 B.C.E.). He prophesied for at least 22 years to about 591 B.C.E., his last dated prophecy being in the 27th year of the exile.

title: John the Baptist was born
details: John was probably born around April

title: Jesus was born
details: Jesus evidently was born in the month of Ethanim (September-October) of the year 2 B.C.E.

title: Jesus was baptized
details: The outpouring of holy spirit at the time of Jesus’ baptism marked the time of his becoming in actual fact the Messiah, or Christ, God’s Anointed One (the use of this title by angels when announcing his birth evidently being in a prophetic sense.

title: Jesus was put to death
details: The death of Jesus Christ took place in the spring, on the Passover Day, Nisan (or Abib) 14, according to the Jewish calendar. (Mt 26:2; Joh 13:1-3; Ex 12:1-6; 13:4) That year the Passover occurred on the sixth day of the week (counted by the Jews as from sundown on Thursday to sundown on Friday). This is evident from John 19:31, which shows that the following day was “a great” sabbath. The day after Passover was always a sabbath, no matter on what day of the week it came. (Le 23:5-7) But when this special Sabbath coincided with the regular Sabbath (the seventh day of the week), it became “a great one.” So Jesus’ death took place on Friday, Nisan 14, by about 3:00 p.m.—Lu 23:44-46.

title: Beginning of the Archaic Period
details: The Archaic period was most noted for the development of the arts even further, particularly through potter and sculpture. Political theory also had its roots here as well as the idea of democracy.

title: Beginning of the Classical Period
details: This period is known for its full creation and implementation of the democratic system. This is the time that people refer to as the Golden Age of Ancient Greece.

title: Beginning of the Hellenistic Period
details: This is the time period between the death of Alexander the Great and the emergence of the Roman Empire as signified by the Battle of Actium in 31 BCE.

title: Jesus was put to death
details: The death of Jesus Christ took place in the spring, on the Passover Day, Nisan (or Abib) 14, according to the Jewish calendar. (Mt 26:2; Joh 13:1-3; Ex 12:1-6; 13:4) That year the Passover occurred on the sixth day of the week (counted by the Jews as from sundown on Thursday to sundown on Friday). This is evident from John 19:31, which shows that the following day was “a great” sabbath. The day after Passover was always a sabbath, no matter on what day of the week it came. (Le 23:5-7) But when this special Sabbath coincided with the regular Sabbath (the seventh day of the week), it became “a great one.” So Jesus’ death took place on Friday, Nisan 14, by about 3:00 p.m.—Lu 23:44-46.
